content.description:
Super classic line and one of the best in the area.  
 Pitch 1 - Solo a cool WI 1 gully of ice and snow to the base of a narrow gap. 
 Pitch 2 - Climb up and through the gap to and belay just below the final steep curtain. 
 Pitch3 - Ascend the curtain (easier on the right) that goes from WI 4 easing off to WI 3 about 2/3 from the top.

This route is found about 300 meters below the confluence of Walton Glen Brook and Little Salmon River on the west bank of the LSR. You can easily see the top pitch from the river and the drainage leading up to it.
A rack of screws. Screw anchor and tree anchor.

Beautiful blue wall of flowing ice. Crux is near the top where it gets steeper. Located 600 meters downstream from the confluence of Walton Glen Brook and Little Salmon River. If the river is frozen continue downstream after Alaska Flashback past a large broad rock wall. Locate the first drainage on the right hand side (west) and start climbing. The first pitch is WI1 climbing a narrow drainage, then gets harder as you get to the wall of ice.
. A rack of screws.

The beauty of this route is its accessability. It allows you to quickly and easily get down to the bottom of the river and access the other lines on lower part of the LSR. Very close to Alaska Flashback, Patricia and Rain Dance Country. At the end of the day throw your rope in your pack and solo this line to the top of the plateau and take an easy stroll back to the car. A far better option than bushwacking up a steep slope. T

On the east bank of the LSR, just downstream from Alaska Flashback and pretty much oposite Blue Steel. Less than a kilometer from the parking spot for the Fundy Footpath access trail.
Screws if you want em but an easy solo for most.

climbs.name: Into the Wild
climbs.fa: Luc Gallant and Michel Martin, Feb. 2021

content.description:
An interesting, varied and spicy route that will get your heart pumping. Start up a thin verglassed slab. You may or may not be able to get a 10 cm screw in this section but good screws above the initial slab. Continue up to the physcial crux,  a 5 meter vertical pillar that is usually quite narrow. Another slabby section will take you to a final headwall then some turf shots to the anchor.



This route is located immediately left of Alaska Flashback. Climb the first half of the first pitch then break left up a vegetated slope to a ledge below the verglassed slab.

A rack of screws. At least 1 short screw. A micro stubby would be a good idea. Rap the route then walk east down a slope to the Little Salmon River.

climbs.name: Iron Clad
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Craig Norris and Michel Martin

content.description:
A surprisingly nice climb. Harder than it looks. Climb the first pitch of Blue Steel then move right to a short headwall of ice.

Located 600 meters downstream from the confluence of Walton Glen Brook and Little Salmon River. If the river is frozen continue downstream after Alaska Flashback past a large broad rock wall. Locate the first drainage on the right hand side (west) and start climbing.
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: Le Ruban d'Or
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Craig Norris, Feb. 2020

content.description:
This is a really enjoyable ice climb. It requires delicate climbing on the lower part up to a steep crux that was protected by slinging a small pillar. This section could easily fatten up later in the season and it would climb like a 3+.  On the fa it felt like a 4. You could belay immediately after the crux at a sloping ledge with a screw anchor or continue to the top. The climb winds its way up a golden ribbon of ice, some places it is narrow enough that you can stem on rock. Finish by going straight up on some overhanging turf sticks for the top out - fun. Step up to a nice ledge and belay off a big spruce.

This route is found in the obvious gully directly opposite the confluence of Walton Glen Brook and the LSR. Walk up the drainage about 80 meters and you should see the route on the right hand side wall. You could climb and rap the route with two ropes 50 meters or longer. It is still possible to rap the route with a singe 60 but you would have to do two raps with the second on v threads.
A rack of 10 screws  including at least 3 stubbies. A few long draws.

Thinly covered slabs of ice for the first 100 feet will test your resolve. Protection can be hard to find. The climbing through this part is not difficult but don't mess up. It gets thicker higher up when you really need it. The final 50 foot curtain can be pumpy.

This route is immediately right of Alaska Flashback. Start on the ice slabs before the narrow gully.
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: My Valentine
climbs.fa: Luc Gallant, Greg Hughes and Michel Martin February 14, 2021

content.description:
If you climb Patricia you can easily do one rappel to a ledge directly below the crux curtain of Patricia. From there throw in some screws and set up a belay for My Valentine. The route starts with a fun traverse right on rock and turf that leads to the ice. Climb the ice to the top. Tree anchor. 



This is the next line right of Patricia. The ice starts about 20 meters off the ground. You must climb the first half of Patricia to get to this route. See above. There are plans to bolt and send a direct start in the future. 

Rack of ice screws. Rap the route with double ropes (1 rappel) or 2 raps on a single.

Long and steep. Super aesthetic line in a secluded gully. Steep and techy start leads to mostly continuous sustained 4+ climbing. 

Found on the west bank of the LSR between Blue Steel/Iron Clad and Alaska Flashback. If you walk the river you can easily find it, otherwise it will be difficult.
A full rack of screws.

Beautiful piece of ice on a wall that has great position. Faces south east so get it while you can.

Locate the drainage for Alaska Flashback 300 meters downstream from the confluence of Walton Glen Brook. Head right (west) up the drainage and the first big slab of ice on the right is Rain Dance Country.
A rack of screws.

Nice long, mellow line left of Rain Dance Country.

Located directly above the start for the lower pitch of Alaska Flashback.
A rack of screws.

Nice long, easy climb with two short vertical curtains. Crux is the broad curtain at the beginning of the 3rd pitch. Top out on the final iced up headwall to a large Spruce tree.

Halfway up the WI1 pitch of Alaska Flashback look for an ice slab leading up a slope on the right. Rap the route.
A rack of screws.
The area contains all the climbs south of the confluence of the Little Salmon River and Walton Glen Brook.
